problem_text:
Let π(G) denote the set of prime divisors of the order of a finite group G. Are there only finitely many finite simple groups G, different from alternating groups, which have a proper subgroup H such that π(H) = π(G)?
V. S. Monakhov
answer: No, there are infinitely many such groups. If G = S4k(2s) and H ∼= Ω−4k(2s), then π(G) = π(H) (V. I. Zenkov, Letter of March, 10, 1994.)
